speaker: Dan
text: Hello and welcome to 6 Minute English. I'm Dan.

speaker: Neil
text: And I'm Neil.

speaker: Dan
text: Now, Neil, do you like going to live football matches?

speaker: Neil
text: Oh yes, I love it.

speaker: Dan
text: Is it better than watching them on TV?

speaker: Neil
text: Well, you don’t really see as much as you do on TV, but then on TV you don’t really feel the atmosphere. You can’t sing along with the chants and songs at home.

speaker: Dan
text: Well, it’s good you mentioned the songs and chants because that is today’s topic. It seems that for some football clubs, the atmosphere in the stadiums is becoming a bit ‘quiet’. Now, before we look at this topic in more detail, here is today’s quiz. As we are talking about football, in which decade was the first ever international football played?

speaker: Dan
text: a)    in the 1870s

speaker: Dan
text: b)    in the 1890s

speaker: Dan
text: c)    in the 1910s

speaker: Neil
text: I could be wrong but I think it was before the turn of the century, so I’ll say the 1890s.

speaker: Dan
text: Well, we'll see if you're right or not later in the show. Now, songs and chants are part of the experience of football matches. But where do they come from? What are they about? Here’s Joe Wilson from BBC Sport. Which team name does he mention?

speaker: wittyhoneda hypnotic repetition
text: Some songs can be witty, honed specifically to celebrate a certain player or moment in a club’s history. Others rely more on a hypnotic repetition of syllables. U-NI-TED, for example.

speaker: Dan
text: So, which team does he mention?

speaker: Neil
text: Well, he used the syllables from United. This isn’t one team as there are quite a few professional teams in Britain that have United in their names, in fact there are over a dozen. Perhaps the most well-known though would be Manchester United.

speaker: Dan
text: I think fans of Welling United might argue with you about that! Anyway, what did Wilson say about the nature of football songs?

speaker: wittyWitty honed
text: He said they could be witty. Witty means funny but in a clever way. He also said that they could be honed.

speaker: Honedhoned
text: Honed is an interesting word here. Something that is honed is carefully crafted, skilfully created and developed over a period of time.

speaker: wittyhonedhypnotic
text: When it comes to witty football songs Wilson describes them as being honed to be about a particular player, or a moment in a club’s history. But these aren’t the only kinds of songs. Another kind of song he describes is the hypnotic repetition of syllables.

speaker: hypnotic
text: Something that is hypnotic repeats again and again – like a magical spell or chant. What’s interesting is that in football songs words can have more syllables than you would expect.

speaker: Neil
text: Oh yes, for example, let’s take England. Two syllables, right?

speaker: Dan
text: Right!

speaker: Neil
text: Wrong! At least in a football stadium it becomes three syllables. Eng – ger – land, Eng – ger – land …

speaker: Dan
text: Alright! Thank you! Let’s listen to Mr Wilson again.

speaker: wittyhoneda hypnotic repetition
text: Some songs can be witty, honed specifically to celebrate a certain player or moment in a club’s history. Others rely more on a hypnotic repetition of syllables. U-NI-TED, for example.

speaker: Dan
text: Now, apparently, in many stadiums, the crowds aren’t singing as much as they used to. Some managers have complained that the fans are too quiet and that this has a negative effect on the players. So what are some of the reasons for this? Here’s BBC Sport’s Joe Wilson again. How many reasons does he mention?

speaker: The decline indemographicsdiscourage
text: The decline in singing may be explained by changing demographics in football attendance. Older supporters, more expensive tickets. Or by stadium design. All-seater arenas may discourage the instinct to stand up and sing.

speaker: decline
text: So, what reasons did he give for the decline in singing, for the fact that singing is getting less common.

speaker: demographicsDemographics
text: He gave a number of reasons. He talked about the change in demographics. Demographics refers to a section of the population that do a particular thing. It can refer to age groups or wealth, for example.

speaker: demographic
text: What Wilson says is that the members that make up a football crowd are changing. They are older and wealthier, and perhaps that is a demographic or group that is less likely to sing in public.

speaker: discourage discourages
text: Another reason he gives is that sitting down might also discourage people from singing. If something discourages you, it makes you not want to do it. Most stadiums in the UK have to have seats and maybe singing is something that people feel happier doing when they are standing up.

speaker: Dan
text: Well the final whistle is about to blow on today’s programme. Before that though, here’s the answer to our quiz question. I asked you when the first international football match took place.

speaker: Neil
text: And I took a guess with the 1890s.

speaker: Dan
text: And that's a red card, I'm afraid, Neil. The first international football match took place in the 1870s between England and Scotland.

speaker: Neil
text: Oh, come on ref!

text: And now, to take us to the whistle, let's review today’s vocabulary.

speaker: witty
text: The first word we had was witty. A kind of humour that is smart and clever.

speaker: honed honing
text: Then we had honed for something that is crafted and improved over time. A bit like my physique. I’ve been honing my body in the gym.

speaker: witty
text: Really? Are you being witty?

speaker: hypnotic
text: I wasn’t trying to! Anyhow, we then heard about hypnotic repetition to describe the effect of thousands of people repeating the syllables of a football team over and over and over and over and over and over and over…

speaker: a decline in
text: OK, Dan! OK, Dan! We use the phrase a decline in to say that something is getting less.

speaker: Demographics
text: Demographics refers to a group or section of the population that is involved a particular activity.

speaker: discourage
text: And finally we had the verb discourage for something that makes us less likely to do something.
